docs.lead_paragraph: New York City is working to determine how extensively it needs to test the strength of concrete in buildings around the city after learning that prosecutors have found evidence that the area's largest testing company often falsified results, William K. Rashbaum reports. The company, Testwell Laboratories, has been hired in recent years to analyze the strength of concrete on a raft of public projects, including work for the city, as well as legions of commercial and residential buildings that were constructed in the area. But investigators for the Manhattan district attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, have discovered evidence indicating that for at least five years, the company has falsified some concrete test results.

headline.main: City Weighs Extent of Concrete Retesting

docs.abstract: Also in the Morning Buzz: Brett Favre's move to New York, a settlement with the Cipriani family to keep their liquor licenses, and more headlines from local papers.

docs.lead_paragraph: As the United Healthcare Workers East threaten a strike, it recognizes that there is little chance that the state, confronted by a huge budget deficit, will make a fistful of dollars available.

headline.main: Health Aides Seek Help From State Over Raises
headline.sub: Asking for New Law As a Strike Looms ;

docs.lead_paragraph: A hospital's chief executive was arrested in what the authorities said was a scheme to recruit homeless people as fake patients and bill government programs for millions of dollars in unnecessary services. Federal agents raided three medical centers, and the City of Los Angeles sued the hospitals, saying they used homeless people as ''human pawns.'' Hospitals in Los Angeles and Orange Counties are accused of submitting bogus bills for hundreds, perhaps thousands, of homeless patients recruited from downtown's Skid Row. Federal agents arrested the executive, Rudra Sabaratnam, of City of Angels Medical Center, and Estill Mitts, operator of a Skid Row health assessment center.

headline.main: California: Hospital Chief Arrested in Patient Scheme, Authorities Say

docs.abstract: Federal agents arrest City of Angels Medical Center chief executive Rudra Sabaratnam and operator of Los Angeles Skid Row health assessment center Estill Mitts in alleged scheme to recruit homeless people as fake patients and bill government programs for millions of dollars in unnecessary services (M)
docs.snippet: A hospital's chief executive was arrested in what the authorities said was a scheme to recruit homeless people as fake  patients and bill government programs for millions of dollars in unnecessary services. Federal agents raided three medical...

docs.lead_paragraph: When I researched my book, way back in 2005, I found a handful of companies -- Axiom, Resources Global Professionals and The Creative Group, to name a few -- seeking to take advantage of the growing number of workers at all levels looking for project-oriented, flexible work. I wrote about those companies in a chapter called "Working the Twenty-First Century Workplace." By now it is possible that there are enough companies in this space that I could fill an entire book.

headline.main: Even Executives Are Becoming Free Agents

docs.abstract: A new company, Epoch, acts as a broker between companies seeking interim executives and executives looking for flexible work arrangements.
docs.snippet: A new company, Epoch, acts as a broker between companies seeking interim executives and executives looking for flexible work arrangements.

docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE - Here on the West Coast, we sort our garbage - or else. We rummage through our food scraps, just ahead of the worms. We take our little canvas bags to the grocery store lest we get caught with the embarrassment of a dreaded paper-or-plastic denouement, and the scorn of neighbors.
docs.abstract: At a time when so many Americans are struggling to keep their jobs and homes, do we really need governments in our major cities enforcing public virtue?
docs.snippet: At a time when so many Americans are struggling to keep their jobs and homes, do we really need governments in our major cities enforcing public virtue?
